{{Other uses of|Mikasa|Mikasa (disambiguation){{!}}Mikasa}} {{Infobox company | name = Mikasa Sports | logo = Mikasa Sports logo.svg | logo_size = | type = [[Kabushiki Kaisha|K.K.]] | predecessor = Masuda Rubber Industries, Myojyo Rubber Industrial Co. | foundation = May, 1917 | founder = | slogan = | location = [[Hiroshima]], [[Japan]] | key_people = Taketoshi Saeki <small>(President)</small> | industry = [[Sports Equipment]] | products = [[List of ball games|Sports balls]] | parent = | net_income = | revenue = [[Japanese yen|¥]]6.5 billion (2010) <ref name=company/> | assets = [[Japanese yen|¥]]120 million (2009) | num_employees = 137 (2010) <ref name=company>[http://www.mikasasports.co.jp/e/company/ Company profile]</ref> | homepage = [http://www.mikasasports.co.jp/e/ www.mikasasports.co.jp] }} [[File:Mikasa Sports.JPG|thumbnail|right|Mikasa headquarters in Nishi-ku.]] [[File:Mikasa VLS300 official beach volleyball.jpg|thumb|Mikasa VLS300 official [[beach volleyball]] (2017)]]
{{nihongo|'''Mikasa Corporation'''|株式会社 ミカサ|''[[Kabushiki Kaisha]] Mikasa''}} is a [[sports equipment]] [[company]] with its corporate headquarters in [[Nishi-ku, Hiroshima|Nishi-ku]], [[Hiroshima, Japan|Hiroshima]], [[Japan]].<ref>"[http://www.mikasasports.co.jp/e/company-profile/ Company Profile]." Mikasa Sports. Retrieved on September 9, 2012. "11-2, 3-chome, Kusunoki-cho, Nishi-ku Hiroshima 733-0002, Japan"</ref><ref>"[http://www.mikasasports.co.jp/company/ 会社概要]." Mikasa Sports. Retrieved on September 9, 2013. "所在地 広島市西区楠木町3丁目11番2号"</ref>
Their [[Football (ball)|football]], [[Basketball (ball)|basketball]], [[Volleyball (ball)|volleyball]], waterpolo and handball are often used for official [[match]]es, [[game]]s and [[competition]]s. Notably, Mikasa volleyballs are the official balls for all [[Fédération Internationale de Volleyball]] worldwide competitions, and numerous domestic leagues outside of North America.<ref name=mikasaweb>http://www.mikasasports.com/</ref>
Mikasa volleyballs are the official ball for the [[Olympics]]. Presently clubs, regions, high schools, colleges, and tournaments throughout the U.S. use Mikasa volleyballs.
==Products== Mikasa makes many different types of balls, including goods for [[basketball]], [[beach volleyball|beach]] and [[indoor volleyball|indoor]] volleyball, [[association football|football]], [[rugby union]], [[waterpolo]], [[korfball]], [[American football]] and [[rugby football]] (the last two, only in the [[United States]]).<ref>[http://www.mikasasports.com/sports/ Mikasa Sports USA - Products manufactured] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714092436/http://www.mikasasports.com/sports/ |date=2011-07-14 }}</ref>
==Sponsorships== Mikasa has been the official ball provider of the following leagues and associations, as well as it has exclusive agreements with some prominent athletes:
===Volleyball===
====International Volleyball Confederations and Tournaments==== *[[Summer Olympics]] *[[Men's European Volleyball Championship]], [[Women's European Volleyball Championship]] *[[FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship]], [[FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship]] *[[Volleyball World Grand Champions Cup]] *[[FIVB Volleyball Men's World Cup]], [[FIVB Volleyball Women's World Cup]]
====National teams==== *{{flagicon|AZE}} [[Azerbaijan men's national volleyball team|Men]] / [[Azerbaijan women's national volleyball team|Women]] *{{flagicon|ALG}} [[Algeria men's national volleyball team|Men]] / [[Algeria women's national volleyball team|Women]] *{{flagicon|CRO}} [[Croatia men's national volleyball team|Men]] / [[Croatia women's national volleyball team|Women]] *{{flagicon|MNE}} [[Montenegro men's national volleyball team|Men]] / [[Montenegro women's national volleyball team|Women]] *{{flagicon|TUR}} [[Turkey men's national volleyball team|Men]] / [[Turkey women's national volleyball team|Women]] *{{flagicon|QAT}} [[Qatar men's national volleyball team|Men]] / [[Qatar women's national volleyball team|Women]] *{{flagicon|MAS}} [[Malaysia men's national volleyball team|Men]] / [[Malaysia women's national volleyball team|Women]] *{{flagicon|SLO}} [[Slovenia men's national volleyball team|Men]] / [[Slovenia women's national volleyball team|Women]]
====Club==== *{{flagicon|ITA}} [[Sir Safety Umbria Volley|Perugia]]
====Athletes==== *{{flagicon|USA}} [[Misty May-Treanor]] *{{flagicon|USA}} [[Reid Priddy]] *{{flagicon|ITA}} [[Marta Menegatti]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mikasasports.co.jp/e/beachvolley/new-sponsorship-contract-between-mikasa-corporation-and-marta-menegatti/|title=New sponsorship contract between MIKASA Corporation and Marta Menegatti|publisher=Mikasa Sports|date=February 7, 2014}}</ref> *{{flagicon|USA}} [[Sara Hughes]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mikasasports.co.jp/e/news/mikasa-signs-beach-volleyball-phenom-sara-hughes/|title=Mikasa Signs Beach Volleyball Phenom Sara Hughes|publisher=Mikasa Sports|date=June 26, 2017}}</ref>
===Waterpolo=== * [[Ligue Européenne de Natation]] * [[Fédération Internationale de Natation]] (men and women) * [[Summer Olympics]] *{{flagicon|USA}} [[Tony Azevedo]] *{{flagicon|USA}} National [[United States men's national water polo team|men]] and [[United States women's national water polo team|women]] teams *{{flagicon|USA}} [[NCAA]]
===Multi sports=== *[[Universiade]] *[[Asian Games]]
==Manufacturing conditions== Mikasa manufactures products in [[Thailand]] and has been accused of [[workplace bullying|workplace brutality]] and [[human rights]] violations in some factories. The [[International Trade Union Confederation]], published a report alleging "systematic anti-union campaigns" by Mikasa.<ref name="ituc">2007 Annual Survey of violations of trade union rights - Thailand: Violations in 2006, International Trade Union Confederation, 2007, [http://survey07.ituc-csi.org/getcountry.php?IDCountry=THA&IDLang=EN survey07.ituc-csi.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726195904/http://survey07.ituc-csi.org/getcountry.php?IDCountry=THA&IDLang=EN |date=2011-07-26 }}</ref> The report detailed various allegations: {{cquote|Supervisors intensively monitored and penalised union leaders through discriminatory transfers and disciplinary procedures for trumped up infractions. Union committee members were prevented from working overtime, compelled to take unpaid leave, separated from their fellow workers, and publicly humiliated by senior managers, in one case destroying their work then ordering them to fix it. When three union committee members publicly protested against the factory’s actions against workers, the management sued them in court for defamation.
When a union committee member who was pregnant [[miscarriage|miscarried]] during her day shift at the factory, she requested the factory to send her to a local hospital. Management refused, and instead sent her to the medical room at the factory, where she was forced to wait until the evening when a friend from another factory came and took her to hospital for treatment.<ref name="ituc" />}} Through such practices, the ITUC argued, Mikasa succeeded in either firing or forcing the resignation of the entire union committee (except the union president), essentially destroying the [[labor rights|right of its workers to organize]].
A separate report, by the Thai Labor Campaign alleged that new Mikasa factory workers received only 173 [[baht]] per day ([[USD|$]]4.36 per day) in 2006.<ref name="tlc">The Life of Football Factory Workers in Thailand, Junya Lek Yimprasert, Thai Labor Campaign, June 30, 2006, [http://www.cleanclothes.org/documents/Life_football_workers_of_thailand.pdf PDF from CleanClothes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613061029/http://cleanclothes.org/documents/Life_football_workers_of_thailand.pdf |date=2010-06-13 }}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:Mikasa Official Basketball.JPG|A Mikasa basketball. Image:Beach volleyball ball.jpg|A beach volleyball resting on a sand court. Image:Volleyball Mikasa 2006.jpg|A blue, yellow, and white indoor volleyball by the company. Image:NewWaterPoloBall.JPG|A men's water polo game ball sits on a pool deck. </gallery>

Sports and Leisure International d/b/a Mikasa Sports, Civil Action No. 96–713LHM (U.S.D.C. C.D. Cal.).

{{Use Australian English|date=January 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} [[File:Morphetteville RC 01.jpg|thumb|right|300px|View of the racecourse and winners circle from the grandstand]] {{coord|-34.978076|138.542747|type:landmark_region:AU|format=dms|display=title}} '''Morphettville Racecourse''' is the main [[horse racing]] [[race track|track]] for the [[Australian]] state of [[South Australia]]. It is situated in the [[Adelaide]] suburb of [[Morphettville, South Australia|Morphettville]], and is about 10 km from the [[Adelaide city centre]]. It is home to the [[South Australian Jockey Club]].
==History== After years of using grounds at the East Parklands ("The Old Adelaide Racecourse", later known as [[Victoria Park, Adelaide|Victoria Park]]) rented from the Adelaide City Council, a group which became the [[South Australian Jockey Club]] began using a racecourse ("Thebarton Racecourse" or "The Butchers' Course") at present-day [[Mile End, South Australia|Mile End]] formed on grazing land owned by [[E. M. Bagot]] and [[Gabriel Bennett]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article106516117 |title=Fifty Years of Racing (19) |newspaper=[[The Daily Herald (Adelaide)]] |volume=9, |issue=2594 |location=South Australia |date=13 July 1918 |accessdate=30 July 2017 |page=7 |via=National Library of Australia}} Much of Seth Ferry's account is at variance with contemporary news reports.</ref> near the [[River Torrens]] from 1859 to 1869, when the course was abandoned due to insufficient patronage. After five or six years of existence in name only, the SAJC acquired, thanks to the generosity of Sir [[Thomas Elder]], its own freehold property at Morphettville ("The Bay of Biscay Course") and held its first meeting there on 3 January 1876.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article31963998 |title=South Australian Jockey Club |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The South Australian Advertiser (Adelaide, SA : 1858 - 1889)]] |location=Adelaide, SA |date=4 January 1876 |accessdate=2 January 2014 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> A breakaway group, which became the [[Adelaide Racing Club]], continued to hold race meetings at "The Old Racecourse".
In 2008, firstly [[Victoria Park, Adelaide|Victoria Park]], and then in 2009 [[Cheltenham Park Racecourse|Cheltenham Park]] were discontinued as racing facilities in South Australia, and now races are conducted only at Morphettville.
==Race courses== The course proper at Morphettville is a long, flat course with a circumference of 2,307 metres. The track is 32 metres wide and features wide turns with a camber of 4% that provide every chance for strong finishers. A retractable winning post with hydraulics enables the SAJC the flexibility to alternate the running of races with minimal damage to both tracks especially with races taking place mid week and increased racing through the winter months. It was installed in 2009, and is a world first.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}}
The second track, known as "The Parks", was official opened in June 2009. The Morphettville Parks track has a circumference of 2100 metres, and the track is 25 m wide and 5% chamber on the turns. It provides a fair chance for all runners. A chute through the centre of the course that runs between the 850 m and 1,550 m points provides for 1250, 1300 and 1400 metre starts.
==Wetlands== The Morphettville Racecourse Wetland was an initiative of the Patawalonga Catchment Water Management Board and the [[South Australian Jockey Club]]. It was constructed by the Board and the Jockey Club during 2001/2002.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.naturalresources.sa.gov.au/files/sharedassets/adelaide_and_mt_lofty_ranges/nrm_education/morphettville-wetland-fact.pdf|title=Morphettville Racecourse Wetlands|last=|first=|date=2017-09-19|website=Natural Resources South Australia|access-date=}}</ref> The wetland covers an area of 3.5 hectares, in the middle of the racecourse on the corner of Anzac Highway and Morphett Road. Costing $2.4 million to construct, it includes 100,000 plants, with the soil excavated being used to raise the level of the racecourse track.<ref name=":0" />
The catchment area for the wetland includes stormwater flow from two drains in Bray Street, south of the racecourse. Water enters a sediment pond where floating litter is collected in a net and large materials settle out. The water is then piped into the wetland, where it travels through a series of deep and shallow marshes. An aquifer storage and recovery system (ASR) has been constructed at the wetland. The water flowing out of the wetland is ideal for irrigation as it has very low salinity. During winter months, water is captured and pumped into a tertiary limestone aquifer below the racecourse. During the summer months, the water in the aquifer is recovered and used for irrigation. Up to 600 megalitres of water a year is recharged into the aquifer, which exceeds the amount required to irrigate the racecourse.<ref name=":0" />
==Access== The racecourse is just off Anzac Highway, Morphett Rd, Morphettville. Entry is via Morphett Rd entrance or Tramway entrance. The [[Glenelg Tram]] operates throughout the day from North Tce, and Victoria Square (Adelaide), through to Moseley Square (Glenelg). The tram stops on Morphett Road adjacent to the Morphettville Racecourse (Stop 12). A taxi rank is located inside the Members' Car Park, where taxis will make pick ups and drop offs throughout the day. Car parking at Morphettville can be found at the following locations: Morphett Road Adjacent to the Members' entrance on the opposite side of the road to the racecourse. Anzac Highway, Morphettville Junction car park, entrance to the racecourse over the tram line.
== Races == [[File:Morphetteville RC 02.jpg|thumb|right|300px|View of the main grandstand]] The following is a list of [[Group races]] which are run at Morphettville Racecourse.

(became [[Sucre F.C.]])| ground = Polideportivo El Cristal, [[Buenaventura, Valle del Cauca|Buenaventura]], [[Colombia]] | capacity = 3000| chairman = [[Image:Flag of Colombia.svg|20px|Colombian]] Nelson Soto Duque| manager = | league = [[Categoría Primera B]] | season = 2010 | position = None| }} '''Pacífico F.C.''' was a [[Colombia]]n [[football (soccer)]] team, based in [[Buenaventura, Valle del Cauca]], Colombia. The club was founded in 2010 and played in [[Categoría Primera B]]. The club was formerly known as [[Girardot F.C.]] based in [[Girardot, Cundinamarca|Girardot]], which then moved to [[Palmira, Colombia|Palmira]] becoming [[Deportes Palmira]] but due to financial difficulties, the club relocated to [[Buenaventura, Colombia|Buenaventura]] and was rebranded as Pacífico F.C. The club only lasted less than two years after it was moved again and became [[Sucre F.C.]]. {{DEFAULTSORT:Pacifico F.C.}} [[Category:Football clubs in Colombia]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 2010]] [[Category:Categoría Primera B clubs]] {{SouthAm-footyclub-stub}} {{Colombia-sport-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Pride Park Stadium | nickname = Pride Park | image = [[Image:Pride Park.jpg|300px]] | location = Pride Park
[[Derby]]
DE24 8XL | coordinates = {{coord|52|54|54|N|1|26|50|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=it}} | opened = 18 July 1997 | owner = [[Derby County F.C.]] | operator = Derby County F.C. | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[Pound sterling|£]]28 million | architect = Miller Partnership | former_names = iPro Stadium (2013-2016) | tenants = [[Derby County F.C.]] (1997–present) | seating_capacity = 33,597 | record_attendance = 33,597 ([[England national football team|England]] vs. [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]], 25 May 2001) | dimensions = {{convert|105|x|68|m|abbr=on}} |}} '''Pride Park Stadium''', commonly known as '''Pride Park''', is an [[all-seater stadium|all-seater]] [[association football|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Derby]], England, that is the home ground of [[English Football League]] club [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]]. With a capacity of 33,597, it is the [[List of English football stadiums by capacity|16th-largest]] football ground in England and the 20th-largest stadium in the United Kingdom. Located on [[Pride Park]], a business park on the outskirts of Derby city centre, the stadium was built as part of the commercial redevelopment of the area in the 1990s. Derby County have played at the ground since it opened in 1997 as a replacement for their former home, the [[Baseball Ground]]. Due to sponsorship, the venue was officially known as the '''iPro Stadium''' between 2013 and 2016. Pride Park has hosted two full international matches, [[England national football team|England]] vs. [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] in 2001 and [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] vs. [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] in 2010, and several [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] matches. It was also the venue of the 2009 [[FA Women's Cup]] Final. ==History== ===Planning and development=== Before moving to the Pride Park Stadium, [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] had played at the [[Baseball Ground]] since 1895. Although at its peak the ground had held over 40,000 (the record attendance being 41,826 for a match against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in 1969){{cite news| url =https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-derbys-muddy-oasis-of-sulphur-and-spectacle-1260743.html| publisher =The Independent| title =Derby's muddy oasis of sulphur and spectacles | date = 10 May 2010 | location=London | first=Jon | last=Culley}} the [[Taylor Report]], actioned after the [[1988–89 in English football|1989]] [[Hillsborough Disaster]] had seen the legal requirement for English football stadia to become all-seater by [[1994–95 in English football|1994–95 season]] {{cite web |url=http://beehive.thisisderbyshire.co.uk/default.asp?WCI=SiteHome&ID=11165&PageID=65873 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926231650/http://beehive.thisisderbyshire.co.uk/default.asp?WCI=SiteHome&ID=11165&PageID=65873 |archivedate=26 September 2011 |title=From a tip to super stadium in 46 Weeks |publisher= This Is Derbyshire|date=10 May 2004 |accessdate=30 October 2013}} resulting in its capacity dwindling to just 17,500 by the mid-1990s, not enough for the then-ambitious [[Football League Championship|second tier club]]. An additional problem came with the ground's wooden components (considered unacceptable in the wake of the [[Bradford City stadium fire]] in [[1984–85 in English football|1985]]) and, in February 1996, chairman [[Lionel Pickering]] made the decision to move the club to a new stadium, having originally planned to rebuild the Baseball Ground as a 26,000-seat stadium. The club originally planned to build a purpose-built 30,000-seat stadium at [[Pride Park]], with 4,000 car parking spaces, restaurant and conference facilities, a fitness centre, a supporters club and new training ground. A year later the stadium plan was changed to become part of a £46 million project by the Stadivarios group that would also include a 10,000-seat indoor arena. [[Peter Gadsby]], however, the club's associate director at the time and head of the Miller Birch construction company, felt the project was both too ambitious and expensive and instead plans were drawn up by new Chairman [[Lionel Pickering]] to modernise and extend the Baseball Ground to hold 26,000,{{cite web |url=http://www.prideparkstadium.com/web/pridepark/history |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830074458/http://www.prideparkstadium.com/web/pridepark/history |archivedate=30 August 2010 |title=Pride Park Stadium – History |publisher= Pride Park Stadium |accessdate=30 October 2013}} at a cost of £10 million. However, despite signing a construction agreement with [[Taylor Woodrow]], Gadsby suggested the club make a second attempt at securing the then-redeveloping Pride Park [[business park]], settling with [[Derby City Council]] for a smaller site than previously agreed. On 21 February 1996, prior to a match against [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] at The Baseball Ground, the club announced to supporters the decision to move to a £16 million state-of-the-art stadium for the start of the [[1997–98 in English football|1997–98 season]]. Derby City Council were paid £1.8 million for the land and the club's four directors – Lionel Pickering, Peter Gadsby, Stuart Webb and John Kirkland each paid £2.5 million towards a package deal to pay for the stadium. The stadium itself was based upon [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]]'s [[Riverside Stadium]], which opened in 1995, though it had more than 30 amendments to the original plans. After toying with the idea of naming the new ground "The New Baseball Ground", it was settled that the club's new home would be called The Pride Park Stadium. ===Construction=== Engaging the same architects as Middlesbrough (The Miller Partnership){{cite book |last= Mortimer|first= Gerald |title= Derby County: The Complete Record|publisher=Breedon Books|year= 2006|page=56|isbn= 1-85983-517-1}} Derby's plans predominantly followed those of the Riverside Stadium, with the first stage being a detached main stand facing a horseshoe running unbroken round the other three sides, with the possibility of the corners being filled in later and the ground's capacity being increased if and when necessary by raising the horseshoe roof.{{cite book |last= Mortimer|first= Gerald |title= Derby County: The Complete Record|publisher=Breedon Books|year= 2006|page=55|isbn= 1-85983-517-1}}{{Quote box|width=20%|align=left|quote="From my youth I only remember this area as railway sidings and a municipal tip and what has happened to Pride Park is wonderful for Derby. So many businesses were attracted to the site once we had moved. I still get a buzz when I arrive for a home game – it’s a dramatic sight, a true county landmark."|source=- Lionel Pickering }} Pickering laid the foundation stone in November 1995 and, after decontamination, the first of the more than 1,000 pre-cast concrete piles was sunk in September 1996. This was followed by 6,500 tonnes of concrete and more than 2,100 tonnes of steelwork as the ground began to take shape. Tapping into the excitement amongst supporters, the club set up a visitors centre which included a computer-generated tour of the stadium taking shape and attracted more than 75,000 fans. The opportunity was also made available for supporters to buy special bricks – on to which they could engrave a message of their choosing – which would be set around the outside of the completed stadium. The weather of the 1996 winter was not kind to the contractors but extra urgency was provided by the news that the stadium was to be opened by the [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen]]. This news – the first time the Queen had opened a new football stadium – ensured that the workers, at one point behind schedule, had to pull out all of the stops to get the stadium completed in time. The pitch stood at {{convert|105|m}} long and {{convert|68|m}} wide, meeting the requirements for an international venue, and measured {{convert|5|yd|spell=in}} longer and {{convert|4|yd|spell=in}} wider than the pitch at the Baseball Ground. It also came with a {{convert|3|m|spell=in|adj=on}} grass margin. ===Opening=== [[Image:PPS-EastStand01.JPG|thumb|right|300px|The East Stand.]] The Queen opened the stadium on 18 July 1997 in front of 30,000 spectators. By this time the south west corner, which stood between the main stand and the horseshoe, had been completed. The interest from potential corporate clients had been so high that Pickering pressed the board to go the full distance with the stadium, raising the final initial costs of completing the stadium to £22 million. Work was still in progress on the remaining corner on the opening day, leaving [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]] to jokingly ask Taylor Woodrow contract manager Ross Walters, "Haven't you been paid yet?"{{cite book |last= Mortimer|first= Gerald |title= Derby County: The Complete Record|publisher=Breedon Books|year= 2006|page=57|isbn= 1-85983-517-1}} An overture to the opening ceremony came two weeks later, on 4 August 1997, with the first ever game at Pride Park Stadium being played against [[Football in Italy|Italian]] side [[U.C. Sampdoria|Sampdoria]], the match ending in a 1–0 defeat with [[Vincenzo Montella]] scoring the only goal of the game. The attendance of 29,041 was the highest for a Derby County home game in 20 years.{{cite news| url =http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Leaving-grand-old-Baseball-Ground-heartbreaking/story-16881086-detail/story.html| publisher =''Derby Telegraph''| title =Leaving grand old Baseball Ground was heartbreaking but we're set for the future with our shiny new stadium| date =12 September 2012| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150924001856/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Leaving-grand-old-Baseball-Ground-heartbreaking/story-16881086-detail/story.html| archivedate =24 September 2015| df =dmy-all}}{{cite web |url=http://www.dcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10270~1056118,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009174504/http://www.dcfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10270~1056118,00.html |archivedate=9 October 2007 |title=Europeans at Pride Park |publisher= dcfc.co.uk|date=21 June 2007 |accessdate=30 October 2013}} The fixture kicked off a tradition of pre-season friendlies being held against European teams at the ground, with [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] (twice), [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]], [[Athletic Bilbao]], [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]], [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] and [[RCD Mallorca|Mallorca]] all visiting the stadium over the next six years. The first competitive fixture to be completed at the new stadium came on 30 August 1997 and ended in a 1–0 win against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] in front of 27,232, with [[Stefano Eranio]] scoring the only goal from the penalty spot. The stadium's inaugural competitive fixture against [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]] was called off with the score at 2–1 after the floodlights went out in the 11th minute of the second half. Referee [[Uriah Rennie]] abandoned the match following a delay of more than half-an-hour while engineers tried unsuccessfully to restart two failed generators. Gadsby said, "We had 11 maintenance people on duty including six electricians but nobody has yet worked out why both generators failed. There was a bang of such strength that it fused them both."{{cite news| url =https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-derbys-big-night-ends-in-the-dark-1245444.html| publisher =The Independent| title = Derby's big night ends in the dark | date = 14 August 1997 | location=London | first=Phil | last=Shaw}} This proved to be the only major problem with the new stadium, which delivered everything which had been promised of it and went on to gain international recognition. Later additions to the ground raised the capacity to 33,597 and a final cost of £28 million. ===Ownership issues=== Although the financing of the stadium's construction was carefully structured so that the club paid and owned the ground without encroaching on funds reserved for the development of the team, the club's eventual relegation from the top flight in [[2001–02 FA Premier League|2002]] saw it enter financial crisis{{cite news| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/2716241.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| title = Derby counting the cost| date = 2 February 2003 | first=Paul | last=Fletcher}} and eventually it was temporarily entered into [[receivership]] by [[The Co-operative Bank]], who instantly installed a new board composed of [[John Sleightholme]], [[Jeremy Keith]] and Steve Harding, for the cost of £1 each. Financial circumstances worsened as the debt spiralled to £30 million plus and an unpopular{{cite book |last= Mortimer|first= Gerald |title= Derby County: The Complete Record|publisher=Breedon Books|year= 2006|page=58|isbn= 1-85983-517-1}} refinancing scheme was put in place which saw the stadium sold to the "mysterious"{{cite book |last= Mortimer|first= Gerald |title= Derby County: The Complete Record|publisher=Breedon Books|year= 2006|page=39|isbn= 1-85983-517-1}} [[Panama]]-based ABC Corporation and the club paying rent of £1 million a year to play there, which local journalist Gerald Mortimer described as "an affront ... to those who put everything into building [the ground]". The ownership trio of Sleightholme, Keith and Harding were dubbed "The Three Amigos" and, after came under increasing criticism from the Derby's support, in the form of two separate supporters groups, the RamsTrust and the Rams Protest Group (RPG), they eventually sold out to a group of local businessmen, dubbed "The League of Gentlemen" by the local press, led by former board member [[Peter Gadsby]], in April 2006. The Gadsby-led consortium returned Pride Park to club ownership.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4954484.stm|title=Derby takeover deal is completed|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 April 2006}} Three years later, [[Murdo Mackay]], [[Jeremy Keith]] and finance director Andrew McKenzie were charged with taking a secret commission worth £440,625 from the club and were sentenced to a combined seven-and-a-half years in prison.{{cite news |title=Two guilty of club takeover fraud |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/derbyshire/8119183.stm |work=BBC News |date=25 June 2009}} As of August 2009, the club still owed £15 million on the mortgage of the Pride Park Stadium{{cite web| title=Appleby: Rams' finances in fine health| publisher=[[derbytelegraph.co.uk]]| url=http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/finances-fine-health/story-11596332-detail/story.html| date=21 August 2009| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924033920/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/finances-fine-health/story-11596332-detail/story.html| archivedate=24 September 2015| df=dmy-all}} which was later revealed to be due to be paid off in 2016.{{cite web| title=Glick insists owners have a long-term goal as he answers fans' questions on Rams future| publisher=derbytelegraph.co.uk| url=http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Glick-insists-owners-long-term-goal-answers-fans-questions-Rams-future/story-11608260-detail/story.html| date=11 October 2010| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923230911/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Glick-insists-owners-long-term-goal-answers-fans-questions-Rams-future/story-11608260-detail/story.html| archivedate=23 September 2015| df=dmy-all}} ===Pride Plaza redevelopment and ground expansion=== [[Image:Clough and Taylor Statue Derby.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Clough and Taylor statue.]] {{Quote box|width=20%|align=left|quote="In the past 10 years Pride Park Stadium has been a big economic driver for Derby, but while the area itself has become the city's main business location, other stadiums have now been built that combine with traditional football facilities new commercial outlets for those clubs and their fans. "When we first built Pride Park we were always aware of further development potential and when I came back to the club almost 12 months ago with the current Board of Directors we indicated we would look to maximise that potential for the benefit of the club.."|source=- Peter Gadsby{{cite news| url =http://www.bbc.co.uk/derby/content/articles/2007/04/26/pride_park_hotel_development_feature.shtml| publisher = BBC Sport| title = Rams announce £20m Pride Park development| date = 27 April 2007}}}} During the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07 season]], in which Derby earned promotion back to the [[Premier League]] after five years, the club released details of a proposed £20 million development of the area surrounding the stadium, to include the building of a 165-bed hotel, bars, restaurants and office space, to create a local service centre for employers located on the Pride Park business park. Three squares would also be introduced which would be named after legendary figures associated with the club – all-time leading goalscorer [[Steve Bloomer]], the club's greatest manager [[Brian Clough]] and former chairman [[Lionel Pickering]], who had died in 2006. The club insisted no money would be taken away from the team to pay for the development. On 9 November 2007, [[Derby City Council]] agreed to let the plans go ahead. Following promotion to the Premier League in the 2006–07 season, the club announced plans to expand the capacity of the stadium up to 44,000 for the start of the 2008–09 season, if the club successfully survived. The plans included adding rows of seats to the north, south and east stands and would have allowed the club to break its current club record attendance.{{cite web |url=http://www.therams.co.uk/details.asp?back=true&key=1D29%7c0%7c2185366269754%7cR%7c536%7c11372241262007310839232&parentkey=1D29%7c0%7c2185366269754%7cp%7c536%7c0 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080512030900/http://www.therams.co.uk/details.asp?back=true&key=1D29%7C0%7C2185366269754%7CR%7C536%7C11372241262007310839232&parentkey=1D29%7C0%7C2185366269754%7Cp%7C536%7C0 |archivedate=12 May 2008 |title=Rams announce stadium expansion |publisher= therams.co.uk |accessdate=30 October 2013}} The club, however, failed to maintain its top-flight status and when, in January 2008, was sold into new American ownership, in the form of General Sports and Entertainment{{cite news| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7210230.stm| publisher =BBC Sport| title = New owners reveal Derby ambition| date = 28 January 2008}} both the plaza plan and the ground expansion initiatives were scrapped. In 2008, a nine-foot-high bronze statue of [[Brian Clough]] and [[Peter Taylor (footballer, born 1928)|Peter Taylor]] – who had managed the club between 1967 and 1973 – was commissioned to adorn the north west portion of the ground to be called Unity Plaza. The statue was designed by Andrew Edwards and features both Clough and Taylor holding the [[Football League First Division|League Championship]] trophy which they won with the club in [[1971–72 in English football|1972]]. It was unveiled on 27 August 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.dcfc.co.uk/page/CloughTaylorMonument/0,,10270~2083075,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101024222410/http://www.dcfc.co.uk/page/CloughTaylorMonument/0,,10270~2083075,00.html |archivedate=24 October 2010 |title=Rams Name The Date For Clough/Taylor Reveal |publisher= dcfc.co.uk|date=27 August 2010 |accessdate=30 October 2013}} ===2018 World Cup and 2012 Olympic bids=== In 2009, Pride Park was earmarked as a possible [[FIFA World Cup]] venue when Derby County announced its intention to apply to be one of the host cities as part of [[English 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bid|England's bid]] for the 2018 World Cup Finals, with Derby chief executive Tom Glick saying, "What we [the board] know is that Derby already has the core elements to be a host city ... We are going to find out what the requirements are but we are certainly expecting that the requirement would be at least 40,000 seats. The ability to do that at Pride Park Stadium exists, the land exists. So we know that if we were successful, that is something that could be done."{{cite news| url =http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/WORLD-VISION/story-11619146-detail/story.html| publisher =derbytelegraph.co.uk| title =World Vision| date =18 May 2009| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150924013540/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/WORLD-VISION/story-11619146-detail/story.html| archivedate =24 September 2015| df =dmy-all}} [[Image:Pride Park Stadium South Stand.JPG|thumb|left|300px|The South Stand (right).]] To qualify as a host stadium, the ground would need to expand to at least 40,000 capacity and the club announced that three methods could be undertaken to achieve this, two of which would leave the stadium permanently expanded.{{cite news| url =http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Derby-World-Cup-bid-plans-Pride-Park-Stadium-expansion-unveiled/story-11622444-detail/story.html| publisher =''Derbyshire Telegraph''| title =Derby World Cup bid plans for Pride Park Stadium expansion unveiled| date =22 July 2009| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150923225343/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Derby-World-Cup-bid-plans-Pride-Park-Stadium-expansion-unveiled/story-11622444-detail/story.html| archivedate =23 September 2015| df =dmy-all}} Option A would see the additional capacity supplied by temporary stands erected behind each goal, removing the current roof, and be supported by steel structures, with all the stands removed after the World Cup and the original roofing replaced. Option B would also see temporary seating built in the north and south stands as well as an additional structure placed on the east stand which the club could choose to keep, increasing the capacity to 39,000. The final Option, C, would see the removal of seating from the north, south and east stands and three new 20 row decks placed in each stand. This again came with the option of retaining the east stand expansion, raising the stadium capacity to a permanent 37,000. The club itself stated that it preferred to explore temporary, rather than permanent, expansion, saying "We'd like to meet the World Cup standards for matches when it comes to expansion but then perhaps scale down the stadium to something closer to where we are right now. That way, we can keep the intimacy and special atmosphere that has almost become a hallmark of going to a Derby County match. When the team play at home, having a full stadium is a huge advantage because it creates a brilliant atmosphere. What we wouldn't want to do is have a stadium that all of a sudden was too big after the World Cup had gone." On 16 December 2009, Derby's campaign was rejected by the [[The Football Association|FA]], along with [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]] and [[Leicester]] to local rival bid by [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]]. Tom Glick later commented, "We're all greatly disappointed. Thousands of hours of hard work has been put in across the city from a number of agencies. We need to get some feedback as to why the bid was not successful."{{cite news| url =http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/s-arguments-FA-s-decision/story-11586891-detail/story.html| publisher =''Derbyshire Telegraph''| title =It's all over now but arguments over FA's decision to go on| date =17 December 2009| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150924033950/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/s-arguments-FA-s-decision/story-11586891-detail/story.html| archivedate =24 September 2015| df =dmy-all}} The club was later unsuccessful in its attempt to be the [[English Midlands|Midlands]] football venue for the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], losing out to [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]]'s [[Ricoh Arena]],{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8720047.stm|title=Coventry City's Ricoh Arena chosen for Olympics|work=BBC Sport|date=3 June 2010}} with the selection committee citing the fact the stadium "has fewer dressing rooms and no hotel" in comparison to the Coventry-based stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Olympic-snub-Pride-Park/story-11614169-detail/story.html|title=Olympic Snub for Pride Park|work=derbytelegraph.co.uk|date=3 June 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924002230/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Olympic-snub-Pride-Park/story-11614169-detail/story.html|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} ===Additional ground developments=== On 17 January 2009, a [[bust (sculpture)|bust]] of [[Steve Bloomer]] was unveiled next to the home dugout.{{cite web|url=http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Derby-County-Steve-Bloomer-s-watching-statue-unveiled-Pride-Park/story-11643630-detail/story.html|publisher=Derby Evening Telegraph|title=Now Steve Bloomer really is watching|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923224617/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Derby-County-Steve-Bloomer-s-watching-statue-unveiled-Pride-Park/story-11643630-detail/story.html|archivedate=23 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} ===The Plaza @ Pride Park development=== On 3 October 2011, Derby County announced that they had submitted plans to Derby City Council for a £7 million development of land outside the stadium, which the club named "The Plaza @ Pride Park".{{cite news| url =http://www.dcfc.co.uk/news/article/press-release-the-plaza-pride-park-256822.aspx?pageView=full#anchored| publisher = dcfc.co,uk| title = Press Release: The Plaza @ Pride Park| date = 11 October 2011}} These plans include five [[Coffeehouse|cafes]]/[[restaurant]]s, two [[convenience store]]s and 2,000 square metres of [[Office|office space]]. These plans have been scaled down from the planned £20 million pound development proposed in 2007.{{cite news| url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-lincolnshire-15147480| publisher = BBC News| title = Derby County submits plans for new Pride Park plaza| date = 3 October 2011}} Derby County CEO Tom Glick said that these plans would help the club deal with the new Financial Fair Play regulations which will be introduced in the [[The Football League|Football League]] from 2012, as revenue from the plaza will be reinvested back into the club. This planned development also coincides with a plan from the city council to build a multi-use sports arena on the same site as the proposed plaza. On 12 January 2012, [[Derby City Council]]'s planning control committee gave planning permission for the development,{{cite news| url =http://www.dcfc.co.uk/news/article/press-release-planning-consent-approved-256826.aspx| publisher = dcfc.co,uk| title = Council Gives Planning Consent| date = 12 January 2012}} Derby County chief executive Tom Glick said that the club had moved to the next stage of the development, finding a development company to build the plaza. It was announced on 3 May 2013 that the first phase was to be launched after the last game of the [[2012–13 in English football|2012–13 season]] when Derby County faced [[Millwall F.C.|Milwall]]. Located in the north east corner of the stadium and close to the DCFC megastore, the initial phase will provide a mixture of retail and restaurant units totalling 7,000sq.ft. The development is being undertaken jointly by the club and Cedar House Investments, part of former chairman [[Peter Gadsby]]'s Ark Capital group of companies. John Vicars, chief operating officer at Derby County, welcomed the launch by saying, "We see this development attracting perhaps a convenience retailer, and a restaurant to complement the facilities already available on Pride Park and to provide a greater choice. With the opening of the new multi-use sports arena and [[velodrome]] adjacent to the club, there will be even greater demand for these facilities." [[Peter Gadsby]] said: "The area is already a proven destination for leading occupiers including [[Greggs]], [[Frankie & Benny's]], [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]] and [[Starbucks]]. I am particularly keen that this scheme will add to the success of Pride Park and provide further amenities for the 10,000 people that are working in the area. It is good news that this phase of the development will create a further 25 jobs."{{cite news|url=http://www.dcfc.co.uk/news/article/the-plaza-pride-park-first-phase-805700.aspx|title=The Plaza @ Pride Park: First Phase|date=3 May 2013|publisher=dcfc.co.uk}} A phase 2 of the plaza will be considered once the velodrome has opened and will add further to the vitality and vibrancy of Pride Park. Derby-based FHP have been appointed as [[letting agent]]s for the scheme. ===Renaming the stadium=== On 7 December 2013, Pride Park was renamed the iPro Stadium in a £7 million sponsorship deal with global sports' drink company iPro.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2506858/Derby-Pride-Park-The-iPro-Stadium.html?ico=sport^headlines|title=Derby re-name Pride Park 'The iPro Stadium' with club set to net £7m|last=Moxley|first=Neil|date=13 November 2013|work=[[Daily Mail]]|publisher=[[DMG Media]]|accessdate=13 November 2013}} The club announced the cancellation of the sponsorship deal on 18 November 2016, reverting the stadium's name back to Pride Park.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dcfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/derby-countys-home-to-revert-back-to-pride-park-stadium-3421938.aspx|title=Derby County’s Home To Revert Back To Pride Park Stadium|last=Media|first=DCFC|access-date=2016-11-18}} ==Records == The highest attendance at Pride Park Stadium for a competitive Derby County match is 33,378 in a Premier League match against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 18 March 2000. {{wide image|pridepark.jpg|800px|align-cap=center|Panorama taken from the South Stand.}} In a testimonial for Ted McMinn, on 1 May 2006, former players of both Derby County and Rangers contested a match at Derby County's Pride Park Stadium in which a record 33,475 spectators attended – around 10,000 of them being Rangers fans. == Average league attendance == [[Image:Bloomer.JPG|thumb|right|250px|The bust of [[Steve Bloomer]], located adjacent to the home team's dugout.]] {| class="wikitable" |- !Season !Average Attendance !Division !Position grounds in the Midlands, Pride Park has also hosted some notable matches not connected to Derby County. Pride Park has hosted one [[England national football team|full England]] international; a 4–0 friendly victory over [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] on 25 May 2001, when the national side toured the country during the building of the new [[Wembley Stadium]]. The match also holds the record for the highest attendance at the stadium: a full-house of 33,598. The ground has hosted six [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] matches. The results were as follows; {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor=#bdb76b ! Date !! Opponents !! Result !! Attendance !! Part of |- |9 February 1999{{Cite web|url=https://www.11v11.com/matches/england-v-france-09-february-1999-266339/|title=11v11.com|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} |France |2-1 |32,865 of international U21 football, Pride Park was selected as a host venue as part of the English bid to host the 2013 European U21s Championship.{{cite news|url =http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Pride-Park-line-host-Europe-21-champs/story-11627649-detail/story.html|publisher =derbytelegraph.co.uk|title =Pride Park in line to host Europe Under-21 champs|date =19 October 2010|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150924002338/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Pride-Park-line-host-Europe-21-champs/story-11627649-detail/story.html|archivedate =24 September 2015|df =dmy-all}} Away from the England national side, the stadium hosted a friendly between [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] and [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] on 11 October 2010.{{cite news|url =http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Brazil-set-play-Pride-Park-friendly/story-11631543-detail/story.html|publisher =derbytelegraph.co.uk|title =Brazil are set to play at Pride Park in friendly|date =28 September 2010|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150923213836/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Brazil-set-play-Pride-Park-friendly/story-11631543-detail/story.html|archivedate =23 September 2015|df =dmy-all}} The match ended in a 2–0 victory for Brazil, with [[Dani Alves]] and [[Alexandre Pato]] scoring the goals,{{cite news|url =http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/generation-Brazilian-flair-Rams-home-Ukraine-lose-friendly-clash/story-11573271-detail/story.html|publisher =''Derby Telegraph''|title =Next generation of Brazilian flair on show at the Rams' home as Ukraine lose out in friendly clash|date =12 October 2010|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150924033924/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/generation-Brazilian-flair-Rams-home-Ukraine-lose-friendly-clash/story-11573271-detail/story.html|archivedate =24 September 2015|df =dmy-all}} in front of a crowd of 13,088 live spectators and TV viewers in over 100 countries.{{cite news|url =http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Undefined-Headline/story-11609071-detail/story.html|archive-url =https://archive.is/20131030122038/http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/Undefined-Headline/story-11609071-detail/story.html|dead-url =yes|archive-date =30 October 2013|publisher =''Derby Telegraph''|title =Glick: We will try to host more internationals|date =12 October 2010}} Though Brazil coach [[Mano Menezes]] bemoaned the low turnout ("I expected more fans but I think it was a good game"{{cite news|url =http://au.fourfourtwo.com/news/185624,brazil-boss-bemoans-poor-turn-out.aspx|publisher =''FourFourTwo''|title = Brazil boss bemoans poor turnout|date = 12 October 2010}}) though Derby chief executive Tom Glick declared himself relatively pleased with the turnout, saying "I think everybody was hoping that we'd have a sold out crowd of over 30,000 but, realistically, time was working against us. We only had 13 days to sell the tickets and a big crowd just wasn't on the cards. But I think we've proven that we can turn it around, operationally. The promoter, Kentaro, has seen that. So we have done ourselves a favour in terms of bringing something else like this back again and we will continue to pursue things like this." Away from international football, on 4 May 2009 Pride Park hosted the 39th [[FA Women's Cup|FA Women's Cup Final]], which saw [[Arsenal L.F.C.|Arsenal]] run out 2–1 victors over [[Sunderland A.F.C. Women|Sunderland]] to win the cup for a record fourth consecutive time, in front of a crowd of 23,291.{{cite news|url =https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/may/04/womens-fa-cup-final-arsenal-sunderland|publisher =theguardian|title =Arsenal give Vic Akers the right send-off with the wrong performance|date = 4 May 2009 | location=London | first=Tony | last=Leighton}} [[File:Monsterjamderby.jpg|thumb|200px|Monster Jam at Pride Park Stadium.]] ==Notable non-football events== Although primarily a football venue, Pride Park Stadium has also hosted events away from sport. It first hosted singer [[Rod Stewart]] on 26 June 2005 while touring his ''[[Stardust: The Great American Songbook, Volume III]]'' album.{{cite news|url =http://www.bbc.co.uk/derby/content/articles/2005/04/12/rod_stewart_pride_park_event_feature.shtml|publisher =BBC.co.uk|title =Rod to perform at Pride Park|date = 20 June 2006}} This was followed by [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]], who played at the ground as part of the [[Stadium Arcadium tour|tour]] for their ''[[Stadium Arcadium]]'' album on 5 June 2006.{{cite news|url =http://www.nme.com/news/red-hot-chili-peppers/22798|publisher =NME.com|title =Red Hot Chili Peppers debut new tracks in London |date = 14 April 2006}}{{cite news|url =http://www.bbc.co.uk/derby/content/image_galleries/red_hot_chili_peppers_derby_pride_park_gallery.shtml|publisher =BBC.co.uk|title =Events: Red Hot Chili Peppers|date = 6 June 2006}} [[Monster Jam]] came to Pride Park Stadium on 28 & 29 May 2011. {{cn|date=October 2017}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Pride Park Stadium}} * [http://www.prideparkstadium.com/ Pride Park Stadium website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120826044430/http://www.footballgroundguide.com/derby_county/ Football Grounds Guide Article] {{Derby County F.C.}} {{Football League Championship Venues}} {{Premier League venues}} {{Derby}} [[Category:Sports venues in Derby]] [[Category:Derby County F.C. home stadiums]] [[Category:Premier League venues]] [[Category:Football venues in England]] [[Category:Football venues in Derbyshire]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1997]] [[Category:English Football League venues]]

{{ Infobox stadium | name = Quadricentennial Pavilion | nickname = | former_names = UST Sports Complex | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Jcpicsü1780.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | location = [[España Boulevard]], [[Sampaloc, Manila]], Philippines | coordinates = {{coord|14|36|33.80|N|120|59|28.50|E|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = July 29, 2008 | built = 2011 | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | owner = [[University of Santo Tomas]] | operator = | surface = Maple wood (basketball court) | scoreboard = [[S'portable Scoreboards]] | construction_cost = {{Philippine peso|788,676,000}} | suites = | architect = Recio + Casas Architects | project_manager = Asian Technicon Managers and Consultants, Inc. | structural engineer = Aromin & Sy + Associates | services engineer = {{nowrap|R. A. Mojica and Partners}}
{{nowrap|L. R. Punsalan and Associates}}
{{nowrap|NBF Consulting Engineers}} | general_contractor = Hilmarc's Construction Corporation | main_contractors = | capacity = 5,792 | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = 65.98 x 76 sq. m. | acreage = | tenants = [[UST Growling Tigers]] (2012–present) }} The '''Quadricentennial Pavilion''' (originally '''UST Sports Complex''') is a 5,792-seat multi-purpose [[gym]]nasium of the [[University of Santo Tomas]] (UST) located at the site of the former old Engineering Complex and adjacent football field in front of the Roque Ruaño Building. The Quadricentennial Pavilion is one of the building construction projects of the University for its celebration of 400th year of foundation in 2011.[http://www.ust.edu.ph/index.php/2011/639-ust-starts-new-gymnasium-construction-due-at-400th-anniversary.html UST starts new gymnasium construction due at 400th anniversary] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927182549/http://www.ust.edu.ph/index.php/2011/639-ust-starts-new-gymnasium-construction-due-at-400th-anniversary.html |date=September 27, 2011 }}, retrieved 28 January 2010 The new sports complex replaced the old UST Gymnasium which was built in 1933.[http://www.varsitarian.net/news/20110516/78_year_old_gymnasium_demolished_paves_way_for_construction_of_alumni_center 78-year-old gymnasium demolished; paves way for construction of alumni center]. Retrieved 10 February 2012. ==History== [[File:UST Engineering Sports Complex 2008.jpg|thumb|left|The UST Engineering Complex in 2008, which would be later the site of the Quadricentennial Pavilion.]] Since 1933, the university only had the old UST Gymnasium, which was considered then as the biggest gymnasium during its time, as venue to hold practices for its athletes, as well as to hold non-sporting events. In recent years, the student population increased to 40,000, prompting university officials to recognize the need for a new sporting facility within the campus. A groundbreaking ceremony was held on July 29, 2008 after the [[Vatican City|Vatican]] gave its "blessing" to the project as UST is a [[pontifical university]], directly under the supervision of the [[Holy See]].{{cite news|last1=Abulencia|first1=Charizze|last2=de Paz|first2=Mary Athena|title=Vatican OKs sports complex|url=http://varsitarian.net/news/20090715/vatican_oks_sports_complex|accessdate=28 January 2010|publisher=The Varsitarian|date=15 July 2009}} The location of the sports complex lies on the former site of the Engineering Sports Complex that has an open field for softball and football, outdoor basketball courts, a tennis court, a covered basketball court with bleachers, and a canteen. It was originally named as the UST Sports Complex, but the [[Regent|Council of Regents]] announced on October 18, 2011 that the new building will be called the Quadricentennial Pavilion.{{cite web |url=http://www.varsitarian.net/breaking_news/20111118/ust_sports_complex_is_now_quadricentennial_pavilion |title=UST Sports Complex is now 'Quadricentennial Pavilion' |author=Robillos, A.J. |date=2011-11-18 |work=[[The Varsitarian]] |accessdate=2011-11-21 }} Rev. Fr. [[Rolando de la Rosa|Rolando V. de la Rosa]], the former [[Rector Magnificus of the University of Santo Tomas|Rector of the University]], described the then yet to be built facility as more than just a place for events and ceremonies as it will serve as a monument to "the unique and unparalleled holistic" sports development program of the university. The facility was planned to be the home of the UST varsity players and the [[UST Growling Tigers|Growling Tigers]] starting academic year of 2012. ==Architecture and design== [[File:Qpavfacade.jpg|thumb|200px|Facade of the building.|left]] The Quadricentennial Pavilion was designed by chief architect Carmelo Casas, who also designed the UST Carpark Building. The first architectural plan for the facility was made in 2007.{{cite news|title=The Quadricentennial Pavilion: A closer look at the new ‘Tigers’ lair’|url=http://www.varsitarian.net/supplement/neo_centennial_supplement/20120507/the_quadricentennial_pavilion|accessdate=11 May 2012|publisher=The Varsitarian|date=7 May 2012}} For three years before the groundbreaking of the facility in July 2008, Millenium Sports Universal Co. coordinated with Casas in the planning and design stage where they were tasked to create a sporting facility of at least 5,000 seating capacity.{{cite web |url=http://www.philstar.com/thedeanscorner/articlescontent.aspx?articleid=776775&publicationsubcategoryid=69 |title=Thumbs up for new UST gym |last=Henson |first=Joaquin |date=2 February 2012 |work=[[The Philippine Star]] |accessdate=12 February 2012 }} The structure has four storeys with its first floor being elevated to address potential flooding. The dimensions of the sports facility is 65.98 x 76 square-meter and stands on a {{convert|11784.33|sqm|sqft}} lot. A double wall design, by devising two walls separated by a space, was employed for the interior walls of the structure for noise insulation. To minimize solar exposure to the sports venue's interior, louvers were utilized as part of the building's façade. This feature was also used to highlight to emphasize the building's exterior. The project manager the facility was Asian Technicon Managers & Consultants, Inc.{{cite web|title=Completed Projects - Special Category - Others - UST Sports Complex|url=http://www.asiantechnicon.com/completed/special-category.html|website=Asian Technicon|accessdate=12 April 2016}} ==Features== ===Sports=== [[File:Indoor Track.jpg|thumb|200px|right|thumb|The indoor track, viewed from the 3rd floor hallway.]] The dance hall for the [[UST Salinggawi Dance Troupe|Salinggawi Dance Troupe]] as well as training halls for badminton, fencing, judo, table tennis, and taekwondo are located in the ground floor of the Quadricentennial Pavilion. There is also a two-level fitness center on this floor and a gymnastics room. Five lecture rooms for IPEA (Institute of Physical Education and Athletics) is also located on this floor. On the third level, the facility features a two-lane overall track encircling the building. The first floor training facilities and dance hall has a {{convert|2985|sqm|sqft}} of rubberized flooring. Four-storey sports complex mainly features a maplewood hardcourt basketball court on the second floor with rows of seats rising up to the fourth level of the building. The topmost section are accessible from the fourth level while the middle section is accessible from the third level. The court is surrounded by a tiger-stripe border with a tiger's head as another design element. The basketball venue is surrounded by orange, red and yellow seats. In total the Quadricentennial Pavilion has a seating capacity of at least 5,792 people. local-distributor Millenium Sports Universal Co., provided retractable rows of 1,562 polyprothylene chairs. Outside the playing court, the flooring is made up of [[engineered wood]] by Robbins which was also responsible for the wooden court. Maine-base Hussey supplied the retractable rows and chairs up to the fourth level. [[S'portable Scoreboards]] supplied the 4-sided scoreboard of the facility. ===Others=== [[File:Court2.jpg|thumb|The basketball court of the Quadricentennial Pavilion hosting an event during the 2012 IPEA week.]] The second floor holds the offices for IPEA, guidance counselors, and sports science. The institute have a faculty room and other multimedia rooms for students. This floor also hosts two dug-outs and two lounges for coaches. The new gym also serves as a museum that enshrines all the trophies, medals and other memorabilia of various [[UAAP Overall Championship|UAAP championships]] the university has won. Championship banners will also hang from the rafters of the gymnasium.[http://pinoyexchange.com/forums/showthread.php?t=359069 UST gets a new gym], Retrieved 28 January 2010 On the third level, the facility's windows holds posters and memorabilia displaying sporting events and selected Thomasian athletes. On one side facing the Roque Ruano Building are retail spaces for banks and restaurants. The facility is also capable of hosting non-athletic events such as concerts, graduation ceremonies, conferences, and the University mass. ===Utilities=== Its toilets and faucets inside the lavatories and restrooms are automated and the entire vicinity is controlled by a centralized air-conditioning system. A closed circuit television (CCTV) system is also installed in selected areas within the sports venue for security. The CCTV network is controlled from the Information Technology Data room which is located in the second floor of the facility. ===''Campione'' steel sculpture=== The main lobby of the facility features a steel sculpture named ''Campione'' (Spanish: ''champion''), designed by Thomasian artist Joe Datuin. The sculptor won in the 2008 Olympic Committee Sports and Arts contest. == Events == {| class="wikitable" style="width:60%; font-size:90%; text-align:center;" ! style="width:150px;"|Date ! Event ! style="width:40px;"|Ref. |- | 3 September 2016 | align="left"| [[UAAP Season 79|UAAP Season LXXIX]] Ballroom Formation Dance Competition | {{cite news|last1=Valderrama|first1=Aeron|title=UP sweeps inaugural UAAP Ballroom Formation Competition|url=http://tiebreakertimes.com/tbt/up-sweeps-inaugural-uaap-ballroom-formation-competition/65259|access-date=4 September 2016|publisher=Tiebreaker Times|date=3 September 2016}} |- | 10 April 2016 | align="left"| [[PiliPinas Debates 2016 – Metro Manila leg|''PiliPinas Debates 2016'' – Metro Manila leg]] | {{cite news|last1=Dioquino|first1=Rose-an|title=Supporters fill up VP-debate venue and treat the event like a UAAP game|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/562258/news/nation/supporters-fill-up-vp-debate-venue-and-treat-the-event-like-a-uaap-game|access-date=12 April 2016|publisher=GMA News|date=11 April 2016}} |- | 28–29 February 2012 | align="left"| 4th National COCOPEA Congress | [http://mb.com.ph/articles/352646/cocopea-holds-congress-ust COCOPEA holds congress at UST]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, retrieved 6 March 2012 |- | 29 November 2011 | align="left"|10th International Congress International Society of Dacryology and Dry Eye (ISD & DE) | [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rNgKoTrSb70 10th International Congress of ISD & DE 11/29/2011], retrieved 16 May 2012 |- | 16–18 November 2011 | align="left"|7th [[Quacquarelli Symonds]]—Asia Pacific Professional Leaders in Education ''(QS-Apple)'' Conference and Exhibition | [http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/341412/ust-hosts-international-education-conference UST hosts international education conference] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111118080039/http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/341412/ust-hosts-international-education-conference |date=November 18, 2011 }}, retrieved 20 December 2011 |- | 1 October 2011 | align="left"|[[Gawad Kalinga]] 8th Anniversary | [http://www.varsitarian.net/breaking_news/20111001/campus_hosts_gawad_kalinga_anniversary Campus hosts Gawad Kalinga anniversary], retrieved 1 October 2011 |- |} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{UST}} {{Sports venues in the Greater Manila Area}} [[Category:University of Santo Tomas]] revision.text:
The '''Ratzeburg Test''' was a test used to gauge the suitability of individuals for international competitive junior [[Rowing (sport)|rowing]] prior to the use of [[Indoor rower|indoor rowing machines]] for selection. The test was originally developed by the "Academy of Ratzeburg rowing", Germany in 1971. It was employed by the Great Britain Junior rowing team selectors in the late 1970s and early 1980s.
== Elements of the Test == Each element of the test was supervised by one of the GB junior rowing selection team. All parts of the test were completed in succession during an afternoon. The sequence was a timed 3,000 metre run on an athletic track, then a weight lifting test, followed by a gym circuit test.
The weight lifting test consisted of successive [[Power_clean#power_clean|power clean]] lifts at increasing weight until failure. At a given weight, recorded in pounds, a maximum of 3 failures were allowed.
The circuit test counted the number of repetitions performed in one minute for each of the followin exercises:
:Number of Squat Thrusts. :Number of Sit ups with 20 lbs on chest. :Number of Squat jumps of 1 foot over maximum vertical reach. :Number of Sit ups with 20 lbs on chest (again). :Number of Squats with 20 lbs. :Number of Power Cleans of 90 lbs. If any repetition did not meet the standard required it would not be included in the circuit repetitions count.
== Ratzburg Test Index Calculation ==
The subject’s height was measured in centimetres from the floor up to the clavicle (just below the neck) and the subjects weight in kilograms.
Participants were required to score a minimum index value of 20.0 in order to pass to the next stage in the selection process.
Each element of the test had a specific “constant value”. Each empirical value of an element taken for a subject had the respective constant value subtracted to emphasize better scores. :Subject_Height_Constant = 125 :Subject_Weight_Constant = 50 :Power_Clean_Constant = 25 :Circuit_Reps_Constant = 50 :Run_Time_Constant = 450
The calculation was performed as follows:
Ratzburg Test Index Value =
( (Subject_Height_Value – Subject_Height_Constant) x
(Subject_Weight_Value – Subject_Weight_Constant) x
(Power_Clean_Value – Power_Clean_Contant) x
(Circuit_Reps_Value – Circuit_Reps_Constant) )
Divided by
( Run_Time_Value – Run_Time_Constant) x 1,000
==Critique== The test penalised lightweight rowers who would provide a lower weight value into the calculation. This encouraged participants to attempt to increase body weight during the winter season, only losing the weight again after the testing period had completed.
It did however allow those who were physically appropriate for international rowing to be recognised, and created a focus on all round physical fitness in the winter training period rather than only specific rowing fitness.
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121112044445/http://www.ruderwiki.de/wiki_neu/index.php/Ratzeburger_KA_Test Ruderwiki version of the test] *[[:de:Ruderakademie Ratzeburg|Ruderakademie Ratzeburg]] *[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Trainingslehre-Bernd-M%C3%BChlfriedel/dp/3425051210 Training, 1983, Bernd Mühlfriedel, published by Diesterweg Sauerland No. 5121]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Rodney Parade | image = West Stand, Rodney Parade, Newport.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Rodney Parade West Stand | location = Rodney Parade
Rodney Road
[[Newport, Wales|Newport]] [[NP postcode area|NP19 0UU]] | coordinates = {{Coord|51|35|18|N|2|59|16|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | opened = 1877 | publictransit = [[Newport railway station]]
[[Newport bus station]] | owner = [[Welsh Rugby Union]] | operator = Welsh Rugby Union | surface = [[GrassMaster|PlayMaster]] ([[Hybrid grass]]) | construction_cost = | architect = Thomas Douglas-Jones | tenants = [[Dragons (rugby union)|Dragons]]
[[Newport RFC]]
[[Newport County A.F.C.]] | seating_capacity = 8,700 (7,850 for football){{cite web|url=http://www.newport-county.co.uk/news/article/sytner-end-extended-1265237.aspx|title=Sytner End Expansion Complete – News – Newport County|website=newport-county.co.uk|accessdate=13 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/sport/dragons/11879740.Dragons_hoping_for_late_ticket_flurry_for_crunch_Euro_derby_at_Rodney_Parade/|title=Dragons hoping for late ticket flurry for crunch Euro derby at Rodney Parade|website=South Wales Argus|accessdate=13 October 2017}} }} '''Rodney Parade''' is a [[stadium]] in the city of [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], [[South Wales]], owned and operated by the [[Welsh Rugby Union]]. It is located on the east bank of the [[River Usk]] in [[Newport city centre]]. The ground is on Rodney Road, a short walk from the city's central [[Newport bus station|bus]] and [[Newport railway station|railway]] stations via [[Newport Bridge, Newport|Newport Bridge]] or [[Newport City footbridge]]. There is no spectator car park at the ground but a number of [[multi-storey car park]]s are nearby. Rodney Parade is the home ground of [[Dragons (rugby union)|Dragons]] regional [[rugby union]] team and rugby union club [[Newport RFC]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pro12rugby.com/club/newport-gwent-dragons/|title=Dragons|date=1 August 2016|website=pro12rugby.com|accessdate=13 October 2017}} It is also the home ground of [[Newport County A.F.C.|Newport County]] [[Association Football|football]] club, and is the second-oldest sports venue in the [[Football League]], after [[Deepdale]]. However, stadium capacity is reduced for football matches. Newport [[squash (sport)|Squash]] Club has four courts at Rodney Parade. ==Layout== [[File:The view to the north-east from Newport Cathedral - geograph.org.uk - 2509141.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Rodney Parade viewed looking eastwards from [[Newport Cathedral]] across the [[River Usk]]]] [[File:Rodney Parade Gate, Rodney Road.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Rodney Parade memorial gates]] [[File:Rodney Parade East Gate.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Rodney Parade East Gate, Corporation Road]] Rodney Parade has two covered stands: the two-tier Hazell Stand (west) and the Bisley Stand (east) which are along the touchlines of the pitch. The upper tier of the west stand is seated with 1,996 seats, including 40 Press seats and the lower tier is a standing [[Terrace (stadium)|terrace]]. The east stand is all-seated with a 2,526 capacity including 144 seats in 13 hospitality boxes,{{cite web|url=http://www.newportgwentdragons.com/page.aspx?p=268|title=Rodney Parade Bisley Stand|website=newportgwentdragons.com|accessdate=13 October 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120823002037/http://www.newportgwentdragons.com/page.aspx?p=268|archivedate=23 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} food/drink outlets and a gantry for television cameras. The cameras are therefore pointing westward and often show the sun setting over Newport city centre. The North Terrace is uncovered standing and adjoins the uncovered standing terrace on the west touchline alongside the west stand. The south end of the stadium houses players' changing rooms, a media centre and the small uncovered Sytner stand with 222 seats for away football fans. Away football fans are also sited in block F of the east stand giving a total capacity of 1,300 for away football fans. A large video screen was erected at the south end in December 2013. The hospitality suite is located in the north end of the east stand on the upper level. The rugby ticket office and club shop is located at the north end of the East Stand accessed via the main gate to the ground (Gate 4) off Grafton Road. The Newport County ticket office is a separate building just inside Gate 4. To the north of the North Terrace is a floodlit grass training area. Further north, parallel to Grafton Road, is the Rodney Hall function room and the rugby clubhouse/office facilities. ==History== In 1875, the Newport Athletic Club was created, and two years later they secured the use of land at Rodney Parade from [[Godfrey Morgan, 1st Viscount Tredegar]] for their cricket, tennis, rugby and athletics teams. In October 1879 Newport RFC played Cardiff RFC in a floodlit game at Rodney Parade; the first ground to have floodlights installed in Wales.[10] Newport rugby club enjoyed six highly successful seasons, having been unbeaten for six consecutive seasons. Newport sustained their first defeat in the 1870s, they were again unbeaten in seasons 1891-2 and 1922-3. [[Monmouthshire County Cricket Club]] played at Rodney Parade from 1901 to 1934. Newport RFC provided internationals for every one of the four home countries at Rodney Parade, as well as South Africa. Newport were once scheduled for a regular fixture, against Bristol - a team drawn from Welsh, English, Irish and Scottish internationals. The powerful All Blacks of 1924, and the strong Springboks of 1960 were considered fortunate to evade defeat at Rodney Parade. The cricket ground which was on the south of the site no longer exists as the new Maindee primary school was built on the site in 1993 and [[Newport Cricket Club]] relocated to [[Newport International Sports Village]]. Following the [[introduction of regional rugby union teams in Wales]] the [[Dragons (rugby union)|Newport Gwent Dragons]] regional team were formed on 1 April 2003 and shared Rodney Parade with Newport RFC for the 2013-14 season onwards. On 4 September 2007 it was announced that the Rodney Parade site was due to be redeveloped into a 15,000-capacity stadium by the beginning of the 2010-11 rugby union season. The redevelopment was backed by [[Newport City Council]], [[Newport Unlimited]], Newport RFC and Newport Gwent Dragons. The application received planning consent on 11 March 2009. The plan included construction of covered stands at the north and south ends and to provide cover on the currently uncovered stretch of the west touchline terrace. In August 2010 it was announced that the target finish date for the first phase had been put back to the beginning of the 2011–12 rugby union season with the full redevelopment planned to take several years.{{cite web|url=http://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/news/8330800.Work_to_start_on_Rodney_Parade_development/?ref=mr|title=Work to start on Rodney Parade development|website=South Wales Argus|accessdate=13 October 2017}} The new east stand was opened in October 2011 and named the Bisley Stand for sponsorship purposes. In May 2012 it was agreed that [[Newport County A.F.C.|Newport County]] football club would relocate from [[Newport Stadium]] and play its home fixtures at Rodney Parade in an initial three-year deal, the first time that the stadium would host association football matches on a regular basis. In February 2013 Newport County agreed a further 10-year lease to play at Rodney Parade.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/21607160|title=Newport County extend Rodney Parade stay|date=28 February 2013|publisher=|accessdate=13 October 2017|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} In April 2013 Newport Athletic [[Bowls]] Club relocated from Rodney Parade to [[Caerleon]].{{cite web|url=http://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/news/10364182.___Community_destroyed__as_Newport_bowls_club_turfed_out_after_100_years/?ref=mr|title=‘Community destroyed' as Newport bowls club turfed out after 100 years|website=South Wales Argus|accessdate=13 October 2017}} In the summers of 2013 and 2014 new drainage and irrigation systems were installed under the grass playing surface.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-east-wales-23587323|title=Warning over Rodney Parade pitch|first=Neil|last=Prior|date=12 August 2013|publisher=|accessdate=13 October 2017|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} Despite that, serious drainage problems occurred at the end of 2016. Newport County's matches against [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] on 3 September and [[Morecambe F.C.|Morecambe]] on 10 December were abandoned at half-time because the pitch was waterlogged and the [[English Football League]] stepped in to help identify the problem.{{cite news|last1=Phillips|first1=Rob|title=Newport County to get Rodney Parade pitch help from Football League|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38291057|accessdate=2016-12-13|work=BBC Sport|date=2016-12-13}} In March 2017 sale of the ground to the [[Welsh Rugby Union]] was agreed following a vote of [[Newport RFC]] Shareholders.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/rugby-union/39855860 WRU buy Rodney Parade]. The deal included the WRU wholly owning both the ground and the regional rugby union team which was renamed from Newport Gwent Dragons to Dragons. The takeover was completed on 27 June 2017 and work started to install a [[hybrid grass]] pitch for the 2017-18 rugby and football season.{{cite web|url=http://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/sport/football/newportcounty/15385323.Tough_start_fine_by_Exiles_boss_as_pitch_work_is_set_to_begin/#comments-anchor|title=Tough start fine by Exiles boss as pitch work is set to begin|website=South Wales Argus|accessdate=13 October 2017}} ==International matches== Rodney Parade has hosted six full-cap rugby union international matches for the [[Wales national rugby union team]]: {|class="wikitable" ! Date ! Part of ! Opponent !
